The date of Hanegbi's official dismissal and the announcement of Gil Reich's appointment as acting head of the National Security Council, marking a key political shift in Israel's security leadership.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2023 to 2025 encompasses the formation of Hanegbi’s tenure as national security adviser, the escalation of tensions over Gaza policy, and the political fallout following the October 7 attack.

keyTakeAways: Tzachi Hanegbi, Israel’s former national security adviser, has been fired by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu amid growing tensions over Gaza policy.
Hanegbi opposed a full military takeover of Gaza City and advocated for a partial deal with Hamas, creating internal divisions within the government.
Hanegbi admitted personal responsibility for the failures leading to the October 7, 2023 Hamas attack and called for a thorough investigation into the events.
Netanyahu’s government has not yet established a formal investigation commission into the October 7 attacks, prompting criticism from opposition figures like Gadi Eisenkot.
Gil Reich, deputy head of the National Security Council, has been appointed as acting head of the NSC following Hanegbi’s departure.
The firing is seen as a reflection of political infighting and a shift toward more loyalist or compliant security leadership under Netanyahu.
Opposition leaders accuse Netanyahu of evading accountability by replacing officials with 'yes-men' rather than addressing systemic failures.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Israel’s Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has fired national security adviser Tzachi Hanegbi, citing internal disagreements over Gaza policy, particularly Hanegbi’s opposition to a full military takeover of Gaza City and his support for a partial peace deal with Hamas. Hanegbi, who served as NSC head since 2023, publicly admitted personal responsibility for the failures leading to the October 7, 2023 Hamas attack and called for a thorough investigation, which Netanyahu’s government has yet to establish. The move has drawn criticism from opposition figures like Gadi Eisenkot, who accused the government of evading accountability. As a result, Gil Reich, the deputy head of the National Security Council, has been appointed as acting head of the NSC, marking a significant shift in Israel’s security leadership and signaling growing political tensions over the Gaza conflict and post-October 7 response.
title: Israel’s Netanyahu fires national security chief amid Gaza tensions
